AbstractList: This study was conducted to determine the aphicidal effect of a leaf extract of the Atlantic potato cultivar on the performance of green peach aphids. Three concentrations of the leaf extract (100, 75, and 50% potato extract), synthetic pesticide (Beta cypermethrin 4.5%), and distilled water (control) treatments were applied in a greenhouse experiment. The results showed that the synthetic pesticide, which was used as a standard check, caused the maximum aphid mortality, followed by the 100% potato leaf extract. Compared with the other botanical treatments, the 100% extract produced low mean rates of survival, aphids’ average daily reproduction, the number of nymphs per plant, and the number of nymphs per adult. This treatment also increased the accumulation of hydrogen Peroxide (H[sub.2]O[sub.2]) and malondialdehyde (MDA), glutathione-s-transferase, mixed-function oxidase, and carboxylesterase content in the green peach aphid. Moreover, the 100% extract also protected the host plants against green peach aphid attacks by demonstrating higher chlorophyll content, net photosynthesis, above-ground fresh weight, and above-ground dry weight of the host plant. This study demonstrates that the highest concentration of potato (Atlantic cultivar) leaf extract (100% extract) could be used as the appropriate dosage for the control of green peach aphids on potatoes, which could greatly reduce the use of synthetic insecticides and promote ecosystem sustainability.
Author: Gou, Yuping
Lin, Chunyan
Liu, Changzhong
Quandahor, Peter
Snippet: This study was conducted to determine the aphicidal effect of a leaf extract of the Atlantic <h>potato</h> cultivar on the performance of green peach aphids...
Abstract: This study was conducted to determine the aphicidal effect of a leaf extract of the Atlantic potato cultivar on the performance of green peach aphids. Three concentrations of the leaf extract (100, 75, and 50% potato extract), synthetic pesticide (Beta cypermethrin 4.5%), and distilled water (control) treatments were applied in a greenhouse experiment. The results showed that the synthetic pesticide, which was used as a standard check, caused the maximum aphid mortality, followed by the 100% potato leaf extract. Compared with the other botanical treatments, the 100% extract produced low mean rates of survival, aphids’ average daily reproduction, the number of nymphs per plant, and the number of nymphs per adult. This treatment also increased the accumulation of hydrogen Peroxide (H[sub.2]O[sub.2]) and malondialdehyde (MDA), glutathione-s-transferase, mixed-function oxidase, and carboxylesterase content in the green peach aphid. Moreover, the 100% extract also protected the host plants against green peach aphid attacks by demonstrating higher chlorophyll content, net photosynthesis, above-ground fresh weight, and above-ground dry weight of the host plant. Title: An inducible <h>potato</h> (E,E)‐farnesol synthase confers tolerance against bacterial pathogens in <h>potato</h> and tobacco
DatabaseTitle: Algology Mycology and Protozoology Abstracts (Microbiology C)
Copyright: 2022 Society for Experimental Biology and John Wiley & Sons Ltd.
Copyright © 2022 John Wiley & Sons Ltd and the Society for Experimental Biology
AbstractList: Keywords: defense; farnesol synthase; phytosterols; potato; Pseudomonas syringae; Ralstonia solanacearum; terpene synthase; tobacco SUMMARY Terpene synthases (TPSs) have diverse biological functions in plants. Though the roles of TPSs in herbivore defense are well established in many plant species, their role in bacterial defense has been scarce and is emerging. Through functional genomics, here we report the in planta role of potato (Solanum tuberosum) terpene synthase (StTPS18) in bacterial defense. Expression of StTPS18 was highest in leaves and was induced in response to Pseudomonas syringae and methyl jasmonate treatments. The recombinant StTPS18 exhibited bona fide (E,E)-farnesol synthase activity forming a sesquiterpenoid, (E,E)-farnesol as the sole product, utilising (E,E)-farnesyl diphosphate (FPP). Subcellular localization of GFP fusion protein revealed that StTPS18 is localized to the cytosol. Silencing and overexpression of StTPS18 in potato resulted in reduced and enhanced tolerance, respectively, to bacterial pathogens P. syringae and Ralstonia solanacearum. Bacterial growth assay using medium containing (E,E)-farnesol significantly inhibited P. syringae growth. Moreover, StTPS18 overexpressing transgenic potato and Nicotiana tabacum leaves, and (E,E)-farnesol and P. syringae infiltrated potato leaves exhibited elevated expression of sterol pathway and members of pathogenesis-related genes with enhanced phytosterol accumulation. Interestingly, enhanced phytosterols in .sup.13C.sub.3-(E,E)-farnesol infiltrated potato leaves were devoid of any noticeable .sup.13C labeling, indicating no direct utilization of (E,E)-farnesol in phytosterols formation. Furthermore, leaves of StTPS18 overexpressing transgenic lines had no detectable (E,E)-farnesol similar to the control plant, and emitted lower levels of sesquiterpenes than the control. These findings point towards an indirect involvement of StTPS18 and its product (E,E)-farnesol in bacterial defense through upregulation of phytosterol biosynthesis and defense genes. CAPTION(S): FigureS1. RT-qPCR analysis of 18 putative full-length TPSs (identified from potato genome) in Pseudomonas syringae and buffer infiltrated potato leaves. FigureS2. In silico expression of StTPS18 in different tissues. Fragments Per Kilobase of transcript per Million mapped reads (FPKM) values were taken from the potato genome sequencing consortium and plotted as comparative expression. FigureS3. Vector maps of different constructs used for biochemical and in planta characterization of StTPS18 in this study. FigureS4. Expression and purification analysis of recombinant StTPS18. FigureS5. TPS assay using recombinant StTPS18 with GPP and GGPP substrates in presence of different metal ions. FigureS6. Multiple sequence alignment of StTPS18 with previously characterized farnesol synthases from other plant species. FigureS7. Analysis of terpenes emitted by StTPS18 overexpressing lines and wild-type. FigureS8. Generation of transgenic potato using overexpression (pBI121::StTPS18) (a) and silencing (pBI121::StTPS18AS) (b) constructs. FigureS9. Bacterial growth assay in WT and StTPS18 overexpressing transgenic potato leaves. FigureS10. Effect of (E,E)-farnesol infiltration on sterol pathway and defense genes in tobacco leaves. FigureS11. Effect of 13C3-(E,E)-farnesol infiltration on phytosterol formation in potato leaves. FigureS12. Mass spectra analysis of phytosterols identified in control, 13C3-farnesol, and farnesol infiltrated potato leaves FigureS13. Analysis of 13C3-(E,E)-farnesol utilization in phytosterol formation in potato leaves. FigureS14. Generation and screening of transgenic tobacco lines overexpressing StTPS18. FigureS15. Expression analysis of phytosterol pathway and PR genes in wild-type (WT), pBI121, and StTPS18 transgenic tobacco lines. FigureS16. Analysis of phytosterols in transgenic tobacco overexpressing StTPS18. FigureS17. GC-MS analysis of volatiles extracted using CaCl2 from transgenic StTPS18 (line StTPS18_t6) and pBI121 control tobacco plants. TableS1. List of terpene synthases (TPS) identified in potato genome, their accession IDs, and location in the potato genome. TableS2. Representative gene models of all identified terpene synthases in the potato genome. TableS3. GenBank accession numbers of TPSs used in the phylogenetic tree of Figure3a. TableS4. Prediction of subcellular targeting signals in StTPS18 protein. TableS5. List of oligonucleotide primers used in the study. TableS6. List of potato and tobacco genes used in this study for qPCR with their GenBank accession numbers. TableS7. List of identified compounds and their RRI values from transgenic potato line (StTPS18_p5) and WT plants Byline: Varun Dwivedi, Sarma Rajeev Kumar, H. B. Shilpashree, Ram Krishna, Srinivas Rao, Ajit K. Shasany, Shannon B. Olsson, Dinesh A. Nagegowda

SUMMARY Terpene synthases (TPSs) have diverse biological functions in plants. Though the roles of TPSs in herbivore defense are well established in many plant species, their role in bacterial defense has been scarce and is emerging. Through functional genomics, here we report the in planta role of potato ( Solanum tuberosum ) terpene synthase (StTPS18) in bacterial defense. Expression of StTPS18 was highest in leaves and was induced in response to Pseudomonas syringae and methyl jasmonate treatments. The recombinant StTPS18 exhibited bona fide ( E,E )‐farnesol synthase activity forming a sesquiterpenoid, ( E,E )‐farnesol as the sole product, utilising ( E,E )‐farnesyl diphosphate (FPP). Subcellular localization of GFP fusion protein revealed that StTPS18 is localized to the cytosol. Silencing and overexpression of StTPS18 in potato resulted in reduced and enhanced tolerance, respectively, to bacterial pathogens P. syringae and Ralstonia solanacearum . Bacterial growth assay using medium containing ( E,E )‐farnesol significantly inhibited P. syringae growth. Moreover, StTPS18 overexpressing transgenic potato and Nicotiana tabacum leaves, and ( E,E )‐farnesol and P. syringae infiltrated potato leaves exhibited elevated expression of sterol pathway and members of pathogenesis‐related genes with enhanced phytosterol accumulation. Interestingly, enhanced phytosterols in 13 C 3 ‐( E,E )‐farnesol infiltrated potato leaves were devoid of any noticeable 13 C labeling, indicating no direct utilization of ( E,E )‐farnesol in phytosterols formation. Furthermore, leaves of StTPS18 overexpressing transgenic lines had no detectable ( E,E )‐farnesol similar to the control plant, and emitted lower levels of sesquiterpenes than the control. These findings point towards an indirect involvement of StTPS18 and its product ( E,E )‐farnesol in bacterial defense through upregulation of phytosterol biosynthesis and defense genes.
Significance Statement Here we show that a pathogen‐responsive potato sesquiterpene synthase forming ( E,E )‐farnesol confers indirect defense against bacterial pathogens through induced phytosterol biosynthesis and defense response in potato and tobacco. The findings demonstrate an indirect role of ( E,E )‐farnesol in plant biotic stress tolerance.

SUMMARY
Terpene synthases (TPSs) have diverse biological functions in plants. Though the roles of TPSs in herbivore defense are well established in many plant species, their role in bacterial defense has been scarce and is emerging. Through functional genomics, here we report the in planta role of potato (Solanum tuberosum) terpene synthase (StTPS18) in bacterial defense. Expression of StTPS18 was highest in leaves and was induced in response to Pseudomonas syringae and methyl jasmonate treatments. Subcellular localization of GFP fusion protein revealed that StTPS18 is localized to the cytosol. Silencing and overexpression of StTPS18 in potato resulted in reduced and enhanced tolerance, respectively, to bacterial pathogens P. syringae and Ralstonia solanacearum. Bacterial growth assay using medium containing (E,E)‐farnesol significantly inhibited P. syringae growth. Moreover, StTPS18 overexpressing transgenic potato and Nicotiana tabacum leaves, and (E,E)‐farnesol and P. syringae infiltrated potato leaves exhibited elevated expression of sterol pathway and members of pathogenesis‐related genes with enhanced phytosterol accumulation. Interestingly, enhanced phytosterols in 13C3‐(E,E)‐farnesol infiltrated potato leaves were devoid of any noticeable 13C labeling, indicating no direct utilization of (E,E)‐farnesol in phytosterols formation. Furthermore, leaves of StTPS18 overexpressing transgenic lines had no detectable (E,E)‐farnesol similar to the control plant, and emitted lower levels of sesquiterpenes than the control. These findings point towards an indirect involvement of StTPS18 and its product (E,E)‐farnesol in bacterial defense through upregulation of phytosterol biosynthesis and defense genes.
Significance Statement
Here we show that a pathogen‐responsive potato sesquiterpene synthase forming (E,E)‐farnesol confers indirect defense against bacterial pathogens through induced phytosterol biosynthesis and defense response in potato and tobacco. The findings demonstrate an indirect role of (E,E)‐farnesol in plant biotic stress tolerance.

Though the roles of TPSs in herbivore defense are well established in many plant species, their role in bacterial defense has been scarce and is emerging. Abstract:
SUMMARY
Terpene synthases (TPSs) have diverse biological functions in plants. Though the roles of TPSs in herbivore defense are well established in many plant species, their role in bacterial defense has been scarce and is emerging. Through functional genomics, here we report the in planta role of potato (Solanum tuberosum) terpene synthase (StTPS18) in bacterial defense. Expression of StTPS18 was highest in leaves and was induced in response to Pseudomonas syringae and methyl jasmonate treatments. The recombinant StTPS18 exhibited bona fide (E,E)‐farnesol synthase activity forming a sesquiterpenoid, (E,E)‐farnesol as the sole product, utilising (E,E)‐farnesyl diphosphate (FPP). Subcellular localization of GFP fusion protein revealed that StTPS18 is localized to the cytosol. Silencing and overexpression of StTPS18 in potato resulted in reduced and enhanced tolerance, respectively, to bacterial pathogens P. syringae and Ralstonia solanacearum. Bacterial growth assay using medium containing (E,E)‐farnesol significantly inhibited P. syringae growth. Moreover, StTPS18 overexpressing transgenic potato and Nicotiana tabacum leaves, and (E,E)‐farnesol and P. syringae infiltrated potato leaves exhibited elevated expression of sterol pathway and members of pathogenesis‐related genes with enhanced phytosterol accumulation. Interestingly, enhanced phytosterols in 13C3‐(E,E)‐farnesol infiltrated potato leaves were devoid of any noticeable 13C labeling, indicating no direct utilization of (E,E)‐farnesol in phytosterols formation. Furthermore, leaves of StTPS18 overexpressing transgenic lines had no detectable (E,E)‐farnesol similar to the control plant, and emitted lower levels of sesquiterpenes than the control. These findings point towards an indirect involvement of StTPS18 and its product (E,E)‐farnesol in bacterial defense through upregulation of phytosterol biosynthesis and defense genes.
Significance Statement
Here we show that a pathogen‐responsive potato sesquiterpene synthase forming (E,E)‐farnesol confers indirect defense against bacterial pathogens through induced phytosterol biosynthesis and defense response in potato and tobacco. The findings demonstrate an indirect role of (E,E)‐farnesol in plant biotic stress tolerance.

Title: Eradication of <h>Potato</h> Virus S , <h>Potato</h> Virus A , and <h>Potato</h> Virus M From Infected in vitro -Grown <h>Potato</h> Shoots Using in vitro Therapies
Notes: Reviewed by: Giorgio Gambino, Institute for Sustainable Plant Protection (CNR), Italy; Svetlana Kushnarenko, Institute of Plant Biology and Biotechnology, Kazakhstan
Edited by: Walter Chitarra, Council for Agricultural and Economics Research (CREA), Italy
This article was submitted to Plant Biotechnology, a section of the journal Frontiers in Plant Science
Present address: Ranjith Pathirana, Plant & Food Research Australia Pty Ltd., Waite Institute, Urrbrae, SA, Australia

AbstractList: Certain viruses dramatically affect yield and quality of potatoes and have proved difficult to eradicate with current approaches. Here, we describe a reliable and efficient virus eradication method that is high throughput and more efficacious at producing virus-free potato plants than current reported methods. Thermotherapy, chemotherapy, and cryotherapy treatments were tested alone and in combination for ability to eradicate single and mixed Potato virus S (PVS), Potato virus A (PVA), and Potato virus M (PVM) infections from three potato cultivars. Chemotherapy treatments were undertaken on in vitro shoot segments for four weeks in culture medium supplemented with 100 mg L−1 ribavirin. Thermotherapy on in vitro shoot segments was applied for two weeks at 40°C (day) and 28°C (night) with a 16 h photoperiod. Plant vitrification solution 2 (PVS2) and cryotherapy treatments included a shoot tip preculture followed by exposure to PVS2 either without or with liquid nitrogen (LN, cryotherapy) treatment. The virus status of control and recovered plants following therapies was assessed in post-regeneration culture after 3 months and then retested in plants after they had been growing in a greenhouse for a further 3 months. Microtuber production was investigated using in vitro virus-free and virus-infected segments. We found that thermotherapy and cryotherapy (60 min PVS2 + LN) used alone were not effective in virus eradication, while chemotherapy was better but with variable efficacy (20–100%). The most effective result (70–100% virus eradication) was obtained by combining chemotherapy with cryotherapy, or by consecutive chemotherapy, combined chemotherapy and thermotherapy, then cryotherapy treatments irrespective of cultivar. Regrowth following the two best virus eradication treatments was similar ranging from 8.6 to 29% across the three cultivars. The importance of virus removal on yield was reflected in “Dunluce” free of PVS having higher numbers of microtubers and in “V500’ free of PVS and PVA having a greater proportion of microtubers > 5 mm. Our improved procedure has potential for producing virus-free planting material for the potato industry. It could also underpin the global exchange of virus-free germplasm for conservation and breeding programs.

Certain viruses dramatically affect yield and quality of potatoes and have proved difficult to eradicate with current approaches. Here, we describe a reliable and efficient virus eradication method that is high throughput and more efficacious at producing virus-free potato plants than current reported methods. Thermotherapy, chemotherapy, and cryotherapy treatments were tested alone and in combination for ability to eradicate single and mixed
Potato virus S
(PVS),
Potato virus A
(PVA), and
Potato virus M
(PVM) infections from three potato cultivars. Chemotherapy treatments were undertaken on
in vitro
shoot segments for four weeks in culture medium supplemented with 100 mg L
−1
ribavirin. Thermotherapy on
in vitro
shoot segments was applied for two weeks at 40°C (day) and 28°C (night) with a 16 h photoperiod. Plant vitrification solution 2 (PVS2) and cryotherapy treatments included a shoot tip preculture followed by exposure to PVS2 either without or with liquid nitrogen (LN, cryotherapy) treatment. The virus status of control and recovered plants following therapies was assessed in post-regeneration culture after 3 months and then retested in plants after they had been growing in a greenhouse for a further 3 months. Microtuber production was investigated using
in vitro
virus-free and virus-infected segments. We found that thermotherapy and cryotherapy (60 min PVS2 + LN) used alone were not effective in virus eradication, while chemotherapy was better but with variable efficacy (20–100%). The most effective result (70–100% virus eradication) was obtained by combining chemotherapy with cryotherapy, or by consecutive chemotherapy, combined chemotherapy and thermotherapy, then cryotherapy treatments irrespective of cultivar. Regrowth following the two best virus eradication treatments was similar ranging from 8.6 to 29% across the three cultivars. The importance of virus removal on yield was reflected in “Dunluce” free of PVS having higher numbers of microtubers and in “V500’ free of PVS and PVA having a greater proportion of microtubers > 5 mm. Our improved procedure has potential for producing virus-free planting material for the potato industry. It could also underpin the global exchange of virus-free germplasm for conservation and breeding programs.

Certain viruses dramatically affect yield and quality of potatoes and have proved difficult to eradicate with current approaches. Here, we describe a reliable and efficient virus eradication method that is high throughput and more efficacious at producing virus-free potato plants than current reported methods. Thermotherapy, chemotherapy, and cryotherapy treatments were tested alone and in combination for ability to eradicate single and mixed
(PVS),
(PVA), and
(PVM) infections from three potato cultivars. Chemotherapy treatments were undertaken on
shoot segments for four weeks in culture medium supplemented with 100 mg L
ribavirin. Thermotherapy on
shoot segments was applied for two weeks at 40°C (day) and 28°C (night) with a 16 h photoperiod. Plant vitrification solution 2 (PVS2) and cryotherapy treatments included a shoot tip preculture followed by exposure to PVS2 either without or with liquid nitrogen (LN, cryotherapy) treatment. The virus status of control and recovered plants following therapies was assessed in post-regeneration culture after 3 months and then retested in plants after they had been growing in a greenhouse for a further 3 months. Microtuber production was investigated using
virus-free and virus-infected segments. We found that thermotherapy and cryotherapy (60 min PVS2 + LN) used alone were not effective in virus eradication, while chemotherapy was better but with variable efficacy (20-100%). The most effective result (70-100% virus eradication) was obtained by combining chemotherapy with cryotherapy, or by consecutive chemotherapy, combined chemotherapy and thermotherapy, then cryotherapy treatments irrespective of cultivar. Regrowth following the two best virus eradication treatments was similar ranging from 8.6 to 29% across the three cultivars. The importance of virus removal on yield was reflected in "Dunluce" free of PVS having higher numbers of microtubers and in "V500' free of PVS and PVA having a greater proportion of microtubers > 5 mm. Our improved procedure has potential for producing virus-free planting material for the potato industry. It could also underpin the global exchange of virus-free germplasm for conservation and breeding programs.
